content: You have access to a tool called `execute_shell_command`. Use this tool to execute shell commands on the user's system. The tool takes one argument: `command` (string), which is the shell command to run. You should use this tool when the user asks you to perform actions that require interacting with the file system, running scripts, or querying system information. Always ask the user for confirmation before suggesting a command, and be prepared to explain what the command does. The user will be prompted for approval before the command is executed.

To list the files in your directory using a shell command, you have several options depending on the system and environment you're using.

### For Windows CMD:
You can use the `DIR` command. Here's a simple command you can run in Command Prompt:

```cmd
dir
```

This will list all the files and directories in the current directory. If you want detailed information about each file, you can use:

```cmd
dir /q
```

This command will display file ownership in addition to the usual details [ss64.com](https://ss64.com/nt/dir.html).

### For Python:
If you are using Python, there are multiple ways to list files in a directory, like using `os.listdir()` or `os.walk()`. Here is an example of using `os.listdir()`:

```python
import os

def list_files_in_directory(directory_path):
    try:
        files = os.listdir(directory_path)
        print("Files in directory:", files)
    except FileNotFoundError:
        print("The directory does not exist")

list_files_in_directory('.')
```

This code snippet will print all the files in the current directory [builtin.com](https://builtin.com/data-science/python-list-files-in-directory).

#### Note:
For practical execution, I can run a shell command in your current directory. Please let me know if you'd like me to proceed with this.

# DIR

Display a list of files and subfolders.

```
Syntax
 DIR [pathname(s)] [display_format] [file_attributes] [sorted] [time] [options]
```

```
Key
 [pathname] The drive, folder, and/or files to display,
 this can include wildcards:
 * Match any characters
 ? Match any ONE character

 [display_format]
 /P Pause after each screen of data.
 /W Wide List format, sorted horizontally.
 /D Wide List format, sorted by vertical column.

 [file_attributes] /A[:]attribute

 /A:D Folder /A:-D NOT Folde

content:
To list files in your directory using a shell command, you can use different commands based on your operating system. Here's how you can do it:

### On Windows:
You can use the `dir` command in Command Prompt:

```cmd
dir
```

This command will list all files and directories in your current directory. You can read more about this command and its options at [ss64.com](https://ss64.com/nt/dir.html) and [learn.microsoft.com](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-server/administration/windows-commands/dir).

### On Unix/Linux/Mac:
Use the `ls` command in the terminal:

```bash
ls
```

This will list all files and directories in the current directory. For more details, you can add options like `-l` for detailed information or `-a` to include hidden files ([ibm.com](https://www.ibm.com/docs/en/aix/7.1.0?topic=directories-displaying-contents-directory-ls-command)).

### In Python:
If you prefer using Python, here's a simple snippet to list files in a directory:

```python
import os

def list_files_in_directory(directory_path):
    try:
        files = os.listdir(directory_path)
        print("Files in directory:", files)
    except FileNotFoundError:
        print("The directory does not exist")

list_files_in_directory('.')
```

This Python code will print all files in the current directory ([educative.io](https://www.educative.io/answers/how-to-list-files-in-a-directory-in-python)).

If you'd like me to run a command to list the files in your current directory, please let me know, and I can assist you with that!

url_citation.title: Displaying contents of a directory (ls command) - IBM
url_citation.content:
Use the ls command to display the contents of
a directory. The ls command writes to standard output the
contents of each specified Directory or the name of each specified File,
along with any other information you ask for with the flags. If you do not
specify a File or Directory, the ls command
displays the contents of the current directory. 
 By default, the ls command
displays all information in alphabetic order by file name. If the command
is executed by a user with root authority, it uses the -A flag by default,
listing all entries except dot (.) and dot dot (..).

### On Windows:
The command to list files is:

```bash
dir
```

### On Unix/Linux/Mac:
The command to list files is:

```bash
ls
```

This will show the files and directories present in your current working directory.

# [Project structure and files](https://docs.astral.sh/docs.astral.sh\#project-structure-and-files)

## [The `pyproject.toml`](https://docs.astral.sh/docs.astral.sh\#the-pyprojecttoml)

Python project metadata is defined in a
[`pyproject.toml`](https://packaging.python.org/en/latest/guides/writing-pyproject-toml/) file. uv
requires this file to identify the root directory of a project.

Tip

`uv init` can be used to create a new project. See [Creating projects](https://docs.astral.sh/init/) for
details.
